{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2988742,"name":"Sky Captain","username":"Sky_Captain","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sky_captain/{size}/4746_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T01:33:00.067Z","cooked":"

Hi All,

This is a pretty basic issue, but I can’t seem to figure it out. I’m getting a red line on my first line on build.gradle “import edu.wpi.first.gradlerio.deploy.roborio.RoboRIO”

I am getting this message as an error “Unresolved dependency: junit:junit:4.12”

This is from last years program that we imported via the 2021 → 2022 converter. I updated the Rev libraries and changed those small modifications and those errors went away.

Is this enough for y’all to tell me what simple thing I missed? I can post the full code, but I’m assuming I just missed a text box or check somewhere.

Thanks,
Will

Im not an experienced coder and have no idea what the error means, but i can safely say that code from 2021 will most likely break in 2022 due to the WPI libraries having undergone significant changes in some areas.

You’re only getting that error on intellisense, right? The project still builds? You can ignore it in that case. You can usually fix the intellisense warning by running the Clean Java Language Server Workspace command from the command palette in VS Code.

I have a question, (I may be out of the loop here). What 2021 → 2022 converter do you speak of? Is it a WPILib tool?

After installation, you just have to import a 2021 project into 2022 for it to be compatible. WPILib automatically does it for you.

Hi Joe,
I installed WPILIB using the 2022 installer. I removed all of my 2021 versions before installing the '22 stuff. I did the “download” option instead of the install VScode offline. The rest of the installation was standard following the “manual”.
Thanks.

E.Li below this is correct. I cloned our '21 repo to VSCode as we are trying to get our '21 bot to work as our test bed. The first time I opened the '21 code, it prompted me to run it through the “converter”. There were some errors as the REV libraries have changed a bit, but those went away as soon as we fixed them and added the latest REV json file. Hilariously we lost every single software team member as they were all seniors and our new sw team are all rookies. I was pretty hands off for the past 2 years, so I’m scrambling to get familiar with the program they wrote.

That’s the odd thing. The project builds, but it does not deploy. The error occurs when trying to deploy to the robot. I will try your suggestion when I get to the build space tonight. Thanks.

I haven’t tried this myself so I don’t know if this will throw an error, but are you deploying to a roborio with the 2022 image?

Yup, that is the first thing we did. The RIO was imaged with 22, but I can try it again. We also used the 2022 radio config tool and updated the firmware on all of the CAN devices (SRX, SparkMax’s, PDP,PCM, Pigeon).

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T15:11:14.792Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":399602,"topic_slug":"gradle-issue","display_username":"Sky Captain","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48874,"username":"ohowe","name":"Oliver","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ohowe/{size}/221361_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13913,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FTA|CSA|386 Mentor|346 Alumni "},"post_url":"/t/gradle-issue/399602/11","custom_user_title":"FTA|CSA|386 Mentor|346 Alumni ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2989051,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T15:22:34.830Z","cooked":"

Note the project importer creates a new project. Are you opening the new one? You can open build.gradle to confirm the version of the project, the line with GradleRIO in it near the top should read 2022 not 2021. If it says 2021, you probably have the wrong project open and need to re-run the importer following the docs:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Importing a Gradle Project

Due to changes in the project, it is necessary to update the build files for a previous years Gradle project. It is also necessary to import vendor libraries again, since last year’s vendor librari...

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T15:22:34.830Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":38.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":399602,"topic_slug":"gradle-issue","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/vscode-overview/importing-gradle-project.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Importing a Gradle Project — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13913,"username":"Sky_Captain","name":"Sky Captain","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sky_captain/{size}/4746_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/gradle-issue/399602/12","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2989054,"name":"Kevin Clark","username":"kevinclark","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevinclark/{size}/170355_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T15:26:31.166Z","cooked":"

I’ve got a theory but there’s a lot of assumptions here.

Junit, which is a unit testing library, should only be needed when running tests. It seems possible that gradle doesn’t try to pull the dependency while you’re building robot code and then you presumably connect to the robot’s wifi to deploy? At that point it wants to run tests before that push, but you’re no longer on the internet so it can’t download this, previously unneeded, dependency.

So when on your normal net connection, try to run unit tests. You may not have any, but it should pull the dep and then it should be cached for your deployment. Alternatively, stay connected to the net via wifi and plug into the robot directly by Ethernet or usb.

Hope that helps!

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T15:27:16.740Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":399602,"topic_slug":"gradle-issue","display_username":"Kevin Clark","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46009,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Mentor 8033"},"post_url":"/t/gradle-issue/399602/13","custom_user_title":"Lead Mentor 8033","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2989058,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T15:30:45.145Z","cooked":"

The Java gradle plug in provides a “test” command, which is run after compilation whenever you run “gradle build”. Running this test command will prompt gradle to download any test-specific dependencies.

I doubt what you describe is the issue (though I can’t rule it out 100%).

Hi All,

Thanks everyone who has been helping out. I created a new project from the examples included from wpilib. This is the Gears Bot demo. The fact that this build.gradle is also throwing an error leads me to believe that the vscode install is missing something.

image1920×1040 96 KB

I have tried Clean Java Language Server suggestion from @Thad_House the error came back the next time I tried to build.

It still says Build Successful, but I’d like to identify why the error is happening.

Thanks,
Will
